title: 111_hr104
content:
The National Commission on Presidential War Powers and Civil Liberties is established to investigate policies of the Bush Administration related to war powers, including detention, interrogation techniques, extraordinary rendition, and domestic surveillance. Its duties include examining a broad range of activities. The Commission is tasked with investigating relevant facts, circumstances, and laws surrounding activities related to war powers. It will report its findings, conclusions, and recommendations to the President and Congress. The Commission will consider and use other investigations to avoid duplication and operate in a manner consistent with national security. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by various leaders, with restrictions on political party affiliation and government employment. The Commission should consist of 9 members appointed within 120 days, with qualifications in professions like governmental service, law enforcement, and national security. The Commission, once formed with 9 members, can appoint a temporary Chairperson and Vice Chairperson to start operations, including staff hiring. Meetings require a quorum of five members, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Chairperson is appointed by the President, and the Vice Chairperson by the Senate minority leader, based on political party affiliation. The Chairperson and Vice Chairperson of the Commission cannot be from the same political party. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 4. The Commission, under Section 4, has the authority to conduct hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, administer oaths, and issue subpoenas to compel witness testimony and evidence production within the United States. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas to compel witness testimony and evidence production within the United States. Subpoenas may be served at any designated place of hearing within the United States and can be enforced through a court order if refused. The Commission can issue subpoenas to compel testimony and evidence production within the US. Failure to comply may result in civil contempt sanctions by the court. The jurisdiction for enforcing subpoenas lies with the US district court where the person resides or is served. The Commission can issue subpoenas to compel testimony and evidence production within the US. Failure to comply may result in civil contempt sanctions by the court. If a witness fails to comply with a subpoena, the Commission can certify the failure to the US attorney for further action before a grand jury. The United States attorney can receive certification under specific statutes. Closed meetings of the Commission can be held if the President deems it necessary for national security. The Commission can enter into contracts and obtain information from federal agencies for its inquiries. The Commission can obtain information from federal agencies for its inquiries and receive administrative support from the General Services Administration. Other departments and agencies can also provide services, funds, and staff as authorized by law. The Commission may use postal services. The Commission can use postal services and authorize subcommittees, members, or agents to take actions on its behalf as allowed by law. SEC. 5. STAFF OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the Chairperson and Vice Chairperson. Additional staff may be appointed as needed without following certain civil service laws regarding appointments and pay rates. The Commission can appoint individuals as employees under specific sections of the United States Code, allowing them to receive employee benefits. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement and retain their regular employment rights. The Commission can also procure expert services at rates not exceeding those of a level IV position in the Executive Schedule. SEC. 6. COMPENSATION AND TRAVEL EXPENSES.

Each Commission member may be compensated at a rate not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for a level IV position under section 5315 of title 5, United States Code. Members are also allowed travel expenses while performing Commission duties, following the same rules as intermittent Government service employees under section 5703(b) of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 7. SECURITY CLEARANCES FOR COMMISSION MEMBERS AND STAFF. The executive departments and agencies must provide security clearances to Commission members and staff promptly, following existing procedures and requirements. Access to classified information is only granted to those who qualify for such clearance. SEC. 8. REPORTS OF THE COMMISSION; TERMINATION. The Commission must submit an initial report to the President and Congress within 1 year of its first meeting, and a final report within 6 months of the initial report. The Commission and its authorities will terminate 60 days after the final report is submitted. The Commission may use the 60-day period after submitting its final report to conclude its activities, including providing testimony to Congress and disseminating the second report. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $3,000,000 authorized for the Commission to carry out the Act, available until expended or Commission termination.
